alert.note: Alert for Franklin; Oxford (Maine) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued December 18 at 11:43AM EST until December 18 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: The National Weather Service in Gray has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... Rain and Snowmelt in... Southern Franklin County in western Maine... Central Oxford County in western Maine... * Until 700 PM EST Monday. * At 1143 AM EST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain falling across the warned area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Rapid snowmelt is also occurring and will add to the flooding. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Heavy rain producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Farmington, Bethel, Rumford, Jay, Livermore Falls, Dixfield, Kingfield, Canton, Andover and Carrabassett Valley. This includes the following Rec locations... Speckled Mountain, Old Speck Mountain, Saddleback Mountain, Sugarloaf Mountain, Mount Abraham, Grafton Notch, Evans Notch, Mount Blue, Caribou Mountain, Screw Auger Falls, Albany Mountain, Deer Hills, Goose Eye Mountain, Speck Pond, Table Rock, Mount Zircon, Baldpate Mountain, Old Blue Mountain, Bemis Mountain, Spaulding Mountain and Elephant Mountain. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR AND GAUGE INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Life Threatening flooding is occurring. Take action NOW to move to higher ground! If trapped, do not attempt to cross fast moving water. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
